channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Scouting for Firewood, or for Russia? On the Front Line in Ukraine.
item.description: Outside the city of Lyman, Ukrainian troops ran across a 69-year-old Soviet veteran. He was placed in an improvised blindfold. All were enveloped in the fog of war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers escorting a 69-year-old man named Aleksandr, whom they suspected of spying for the Russians, near the city of Lyman in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Russia’s Small Nuclear Arms Are a Risk For Putin and Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has 2,000 small nuclear weapons, but their utility on the battlefield may not be worth the longer-term costs.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.

item.title: Businesses Brace for Currency Chaos in Asia
item.description: A 1997 financial catastrophe casts a long shadow in countries that are seeing the value of their money plunge to record lows.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vendor at a street market in Phuket, Thailand. Many businesses in Asia are being squeezed by the strength of the dollar, which has soared to record levels this year.

item.title: Micron Pledges Up to $100 Billion for Semiconductor Factory in New York
item.description: The company is planning a giant complex in Clay, N.Y., a sign that the government’s investments in semiconductors are steering firms’ decisions.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Micron said high-volume production would start after 2025.

item.title: Stocks Rise Strongly for a Second Day
item.description: The rally brings some relief to Wall Street at the beginning of October, after the previous month ended on a sour note, capping a long streak of losses.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press

item.title: Job Openings Fell in August, but Turnover Was Little Changed
item.description: Government data showed 10.1 million openings, a decline from 11.2 million in July. Overall hiring, quitting and layoffs were fairly steady.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: A job fair in Sunrise, Fla. Data indicate that the labor market remains short of available workers.

item.title: Floridians Hit by a Hurricane and a Housing Crunch
item.description: Losses from the storm are just coming into focus. But what is clear is that recovery will be hardest on people already struggling to make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Audra D. S. Burch, Richard Fausset and Michael Majchrowicz
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., was one of the communities hit hardest by Hurricane Ian.

item.title: Loretta Lynn, Country Music Star and Symbol of Rural Resilience, Dies at 90
item.description: Her powerful voice, playful lyrics and topical songs were a model for generations of country singers and songwriters. So was her life story.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: You Aint Woman Enough (to Take My Man) (Song)
item.media:credit: Waring Abbott/Getty Images
item.media:description: Loretta Lynn performing in 1976 in Rochester, N.Y. Her voice was unmistakable, with its Kentucky drawl, its tensely coiled vibrato and its deep reserves of power.

item.title: Risking Everything to Offer Abortions Across State Lines
item.description: Doctors and midwives in blue states are working to get abortion pills into red states — setting the stage for a historic legal clash.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I just want to scream, ‘This is a public health emergency!’” says Linda Prine, who has worked for years with other providers and organizations to increase access to abortion pills.

item.title: Republicans Rally Behind Herschel Walker After Abortion Report
item.description: The Georgia Senate candidate, who supports a no-exceptions ban on abortion, paid for a girlfriend to have the procedure in 2009, according to The Daily Beast. Mr. Walker denied it, and G.O.P. allies are sticking by him.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Maya King and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Republican leaders signaled on Tuesday that they planned to stand by Herschel Walker after a report that he had paid for a girlfriend’s abortion in 2009.

item.title: What Video Footage Reveals About the Protests in Iran
item.description: The New York Times analyzed dozens of videos circulating online for insights about what is propelling the demonstrations, and how women are leading the movement.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Haley Willis

item.title: Climate Change Comes for the Freezers, a Key Tool for Alaska Natives
item.description: Threatened by stronger storms and a melting permafrost, Indigenous Alaskans are grappling with how to keep the power running to their freezers, which store their traditional subsistence foods.
item.dc:creator: Julia O’Malley
item.media:credit: Katie Basile for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernetta Rivers, in front of one of her chest freezers that survived a storm-related power outage in Hooper Bay, Alaska, on Sept. 23, 2022. Such freezers hold a supply of wild foods that is essential to supplement the high cost of groceries that come by air.

item.title: ‘Beavis and Butt-Head’ Was the ’90s Cartoon That Mattered
item.description: It doesn’t make best-of lists, but the series, then and now, was always much smarter than its characters, and it didn’t try too hard. Sorry, Bart Simpson.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.category: Beavis and Butt-Head Do the Universe (Movie)

item.title: Linda Ronstadt Turns to Recipes for Her Swan Song
item.description: In “Feels Like Home,” the singer, her voice taken by a form of Parkinson’s, tells her story through the border dishes of her Arizona youth.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.category: Feels Like Home: A Song for the Sonoran Borderlands (Book)
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Linda Ronstadt is most at home in the Sonoran desert at places like a friend’s house in the tiny town of Canelo, Ariz.

item.title: The Failed Quest for Community Mental Health Centers in the U.S.
item.description: America has neglected people with serious mental illnesses for far too long.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Animation by Xander Opiyo. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: The Deadly Collision of Racism and Mental Illness
item.description: How can we talk honestly about when mentally ill people commit hate crimes?
item.dc:creator: Eyal Press
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mike McQuade. Photograph by Getty Images/EyeEm Premium

item.title: What a Conservative Therapist Thinks About U.S. Politics and Mental Health
item.description: Conservatives need mental health help, too, but do they need to get it from someone who shares their worldview?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Daum
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times

item.title: To Save America’s Coasts, Don’t Always Rebuild Them
item.description: Taxpayers too often subsidize irresponsible development, with tragic results.
item.dc:creator: Robert S. Young
item.media:credit: Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., after it was hit by Hurricane Ian last Friday.

item.title: The Supreme Court Seems Awfully Nervous About Its Own Legitimacy
item.description: If justice after justice finds it necessary to defend the court’s power, what does that tell you?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Sarah van Rij for The New York Times

item.title: The First Global Deflation Has Begun, and It’s Unclear Just How Painful It Will Be
item.description: We now find ourselves in the midst of the most comprehensive tightening of monetary policy the world has seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Tooze
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images via Getty Images

item.title: California Is Actually Making Progress on Building More Housing
item.description: The state is making it harder for local governments to block construction.
item.dc:creator: Binyamin Appelbaum
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

item.title: Boys and Men Are in Crisis Because Society Is
item.description: A new book has the right diagnosis, but its solutions are too small.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It (Book)
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times

item.title: A Public Health Success Story
item.description: We revisit the subject of Covid and racial inequities.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Andi Rice/Bloomberg
item.media:description: A health care worker from Alabama Regional Medical Services administering a Covid vaccine in Birmingham, Ala., in 2021.

item.title: Another Momentous Term for the Supreme Court
item.description: The justices have already set the United States on a more conservative course. Significant coming cases could continue the trend.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Soon to come before the Supreme Court are major cases on affirmative action, voting and discrimination against gay couples. Several will take on questions about race.

item.title: It’s Time to Take Democrats’ Chances in the House Seriously
item.description: No, they are not favored. But the notion of retaining the chamber is not as far-fetched as it once was.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, before the memorial service last month for Queen Elizabeth II in Washington. Republicans are favored to retake the House.

item.title: After Dobbs: What Is Feminist Sex?
item.description: Michelle Goldberg and Nona Willis Aronowitz on what sexual liberation really means for feminism.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Tear Gas, a Stampede, and an Indonesian Family Shattered
item.description: Muhammad Yulianto and Devi Ratna Sari took their young son to his first soccer match. The young couple were among the 125 who died in the tragedy at the Indonesian stadium.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images
item.media:description: Muhammad Alfiansyah, 11, with photographs of his parents, in Malang on Tuesday.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physics Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work in Quantum Technology
item.description: Alain Aspect, John F. Clauser and Anton Zeilinger were recognized for their experiments in an area that has broad implications for secure information transfer and quantum computing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Cora Engelbrecht and Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Awarding the prize on Tuesday, the committee said that the scientists’ work had “opened doors to another world.”

item.title: Three Huge Supreme Court Cases That Could Change America
item.description: The justices will soon hear major cases on voting rights, affirmative action and partisan gerrymandering. Here’s a preview.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court began its new term on Monday. “There are few signs that the court’s race to the right is slowing,” Adam Liptak reported in The Times.

item.title: Aaron Judge Home Run No. 62 Estimate: 22 Solid Pitches Left
item.description: We estimate that Judge has about 22 solid pitches left to hit a homer in the Yankees’ three remaining games of the regular season.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Ellis
item.media:credit: Nathan Hunsinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge still has a good chance of hitting his 62nd home run of the season, but he has to do it by Wednesday.

item.title: Your Medical Test Results Are Available. But Do You Want to View Them?
item.description: The 21st Century Cures Act gave patients easy access to their health information. Now, some diagnoses delivered without context are causing high anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Diana Ejaita

item.title: Is Teeth Whitening Safe? What to Know and Products to Use
item.description: Many products claim to lighten and brighten your teeth. Here’s what the experts say about them.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Ryan Jenq for The New York Times. Prop Stylist: Laura Woolf

item.title: How To Make Friends As An Adult
item.description: A friendship expert shares strategies for finding connection in a lonely, disconnected world.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Platonic: How the Science of Attachment Can Help You Make -- and Keep -- Friends (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Vanessa Saba; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: How to Give Constructive Feedback
item.description: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Nicolas Ortega

item.title: Pain in Children is Often Ignored. For Children of Color, It’s Even Worse.
item.description: Racial differences in medical care are part of a theme experts are seeing “over and over” again.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: Midnight Basketball Returns, and Brings Community With It
item.description: A once-politicized program has made a comeback, and its organizers hope it can give young Black men a place to escape a troubled city.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Clara Mokri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basketball is a sport predicated on trust. It can build bonds that, in a city like Oakland, might otherwise be found in gangs.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
